oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Eddy Arnold Interview - Jack Taylor - 1963-09-04 - WGN
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Eddy Arnold (songwriter/performer), conducted by Jack Taylor (host) on September 4, 1963 with radio station WGN (Chicago, Ill.)
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Jack Taylor talks about getting Christmas cards from Eddy Arnold -- (00:23) Eddy Arnold thanks Taylor, and talks about living in Brentwood, TN -- (01:25) Arnold talks about spending 75% of his time in Brentwood, and what he does when he is away from home -- (02:25) Arnold talks about what he does while at home, and mentions spending a lot of time finding people work in the music industry -- (03:15) Arnold talks about where his moniker The Tennessee Plowboy came from -- (04:50) Arnold talks about growing up on the cotton fields of west Tennessee, and the difference between a work horse and a work mule -- (05:40) Taylor asks Arnold about when he got his first big break in the music industry -- (05:51) Arnold talks about getting his first record contract -- (06:42) Arnold talks about his first big record, That's How Much I Love You, and how successful it was -- (07:05) Arnold talks about the success of Cattle Call -- (07:39) Arnold talks about his own success, and how it is hard to explain because he does not want to brag -- (08:30) Arnold talks about sincerely putting himself into his recordings -- (09:20) Arnold talks about how he knows a song will sell, and truly loving his craft -- (10:12) Arnold talks about how the songs get chosen that he records -- (11:40) Arnold talks about convincing record labels to do certain songs and albums -- (12:25) Taylor talks about Arnold being a very niche artist, in his own category -- (12:43) Arnold talks about wanting it to be that way -- (13:00) Taylor concludes the interview
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: WGN (Radio station : Chicago, Ill.); Arnold, Eddy, 1918-2008;
